data.title: Howard unveils Tory team
data.text:
Michael Howard has carried out a radical reshuffle of the Tory shadow cabinet, whittling down his main front bench team to 12 people.

In a stark change to Iain Duncan Smith's team of 26, Mr Howard has set up a two-tier team with a reduced shadow cabinet supported by other Tory MPs.

The new Tory leader has also brought back his predecessors John Major, William Hague and Mr Duncan Smith to form an advisory committee with the former chancellor Ken Clarke.

Mr Howard said: "These changes will enable us to use the pool of talent we have more efficiently in order to take our case to the country and show how Conservative policies can provide creative, workable and, above all, an effective alternative to a failing Labour government."

Theresa May loses out, however, being sacked as chairman of the party but staying in the shadow cabinet with responsibility for the environment and transport.

Dr Liam Fox and Lord Saatchi, the advertising guru, take over her role as joint party chairmen while David Curry has been appointed spokesman for local government.

David Willetts continues as shadow work and pensions secretary and takes responsibility for policy co-ordination. Lord Strathclyde, who keeps his job as Leader of the opposition in the Lords, completes the shadow cabinet line-up.

In the lower tier of the Tory front bench, Nicholas Soames returns as shadow defence minister, a portfolio he once held in Mr Major's government, while John Bercow, who quit Mr Duncan Smith's team over gay adoption last year, becomes spokesman on international development affairs.

Alan Duncan has been made shadow secretary for constitutional affairs and Julie Kirkbride wins her first front bench job as shadow secretary for culture, media and sport.

Michael Howard's cabinet in full:

Michael Howard: leader of the Opposition

Oliver Letwin: shadow chancellor

David Davis: shadow home secretary

Michael Ancram: shadow foreign secretary

Tim Yeo: shadow health and education secretary

Liam Fox: co-chairman responsible for campaigning

Lord Saatchi: co-chairman responsible for party management

David Maclean: chief whip

David Willetts: policy co-ordination and shadow pensions secretary

David Curry: shadow local government secretary

Theresa May: shadow environment and transport secretary

Lord Strathclyde: leader of the Lords

Ministerial teams

International affairs: Michael Ancram; Nicholas Soames (defence); John Bercow (international development); James Arbuthnot (trade).

Economic affairs: Oliver Letwin; David Willets; Howard Flight (treasury); Stephen O'Brien (industry); Andrew Mitchell; Laurence Robertson; Andrew Tyrie.

Home, constitutional and legal affairs: David Davis; Dominic Grieve (attorney general); Alan Duncan (constitutional affairs); Julie Kirkbride (culture); Tim Boswell; Eleanor Laing; Jacqui Lait; Humfrey Malins; Patrick Mercer.

Health and education: Tim Yeo; Tim Collins (education); Andrew Lansley (health); Simon Burns; Tim Loughton.

Environment and transport: Theresa May; Caroline Spelman (environment and women); Damian Green (transport); John Whittingdale (agriculture and food); Christopher Chope; Greg Knight: Anne McIntosh.

Local government Wales and Scotland: David Curry; Eric Pickles (local government); Bernard Jenkin (regions); David Lidington (Northern Ireland); Peter Duncan (Scotland); Bill Wiggin (Wales); Geoffrey Clifton-Brown; John Hayes.

Parliament: Lord Strathclyde; David Maclean; Baroness Blatch (deputy leader of the Lords); Lord Kingsland (lord chancellor); Lord Cope of Berkeley (Lords chief whip); Baroness Seccombe (Lords deputy chief whip); Patrick McLoughlin (Commons deputy chief whip); Oliver Heald (leader of the Commons).
